children.definition: Market standard 30-day cure period for representation breaches. Provides reasonable opportunity for correction.
children.name: 30-Day Standard

children.definition: Enhanced lender protection with shortened 15-day cure period for representation breaches.
children.name: 15-Day Accelerated

children.definition: Cure period starts upon 'earlier of notice and knowledge' rather than formal notice only.
children.name: Knowledge-Based Trigger

children.definition: Timeframe to remedy representation breaches before triggering Event of Default. 30-day standard, 15-day accelerated, no cure. 51.6% corpus coverage.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Reps & Warranties Cure Period

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Limited to Borrower and restricted subs; Holdings only in limited circumstances
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: 34 enumerated representations applicable to Holdings and all subsidiaries: org status, capitalization, qualification, power/authority, enforceability, compliance, no defaults, no conflicts, consents, financial statements, no MAE, litigation, labor, property, environmental, taxes, ERISA, subs, margin regs, Investment Company Act, full disclosure, IP, solvency, Patriot/OFAC/FCPA, perfection/priority, location, insurance, holdco status, senior debt status, acquisition docs, use of proceeds, brokers

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 50 (Marketing period); DLS Preferred Row 91 (Representations and Warranties); KCT Cat 3 Item 1; KCT Cat 5 Item 2; Review Template Row 6 (Information); Review Template Row 9 (Countersign date); Review Template Row 22 ([DDTL – conditions to draw]); Review Template Row 49 (Documentation Precedent); Review Template Row 51 (Reps and Warranties); Review Template Row 54 (Financial Statements – annual audits); Review Template Row 131 (Voting); Review Template Row 132 (Assignments – consents); Review Template Row 135 (Assignments – Borrower buybacks); Review Template Row 156 (Other)

children.definition: Corporate/organizational existence and good standing representation. Universal specified rep across all deals.
children.name: Organization & Existence

children.definition: Organizational power, authority to enter loan documents, and binding obligation representation. Covers due authorization and enforceability of obligations.
children.name: Authorization & Enforceability

children.definition: Representation that loan documents do not violate organizational documents, existing agreements, or applicable law. Scope of 'applicable law' is negotiated.
children.name: No Conflict

children.definition: Representation certified by CFO on consolidated group basis. Three tests: balance sheet (assets exceed liabilities), cash flow (can pay debts as they come due), and capital adequacy.
children.name: Solvency
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 56 (Solvency); KCT Cat 5 Item 2

children.definition: Borrower representation that no loan proceeds will be used to fund or facilitate transactions with persons subject to OFAC sanctions, or in sanctioned countries. Typically includes representation that no loan party or beneficial owner is a Sanctioned Person. Reinforced by anti-money-laundering and beneficial ownership certifications. Standard post-2010 requirement driven by bank regulatory obligations.
children.name: Sanctioned Person Representation

children.definition: KCT cat5.2 requires the protective mechanism 'no-sanctioned-person representation' but it is not adequately represented in the ontology.
children.name: no-sanctioned-person representation

children.definition: Representation that loan proceeds used solely for specified purposes (acquisition financing, refinancing, working capital). Margin regulation compliance (Reg U/X).

market_benchmarks.dual_rep_adoption_rate__person___use_of_: [cat5.2] KCT cat5.2 requires prevalence/severity data for 'dual-rep adoption rate (person + use of proceeds)' but no existing node provides this benchmark.
market_benchmarks.prevalence_of_sanctions_reps: [cat5.2] KCT cat5.2 requires prevalence/severity data for 'prevalence of sanctions reps' but no existing node provides this benchmark.
market_benchmarks.sanctions_eod_severity: [cat5.2] KCT cat5.2 requires prevalence/severity data for 'sanctions EoD severity' but no existing node provides this benchmark.

children.name: Use of Proceeds

children.definition: Investment Company Act, FCPA, OFAC/Patriot Act/sanctions compliance representations. Federally mandated specified reps that cannot be waived.
children.name: Regulatory Compliance Reps

children.definition: Creation, validity, and perfection of security interests in collateral. Ties to collateral scope and perfection requirements in credit protection domain.
children.name: Security Interest Perfection

children.definition: Representations and warranties that apply only in specified circumstances (such as initial funding or incremental facility incurrence) rather than on every borrowing date. These are additional to the core 'specified representations' and give lenders extra diligence comfort for material events while avoiding impediments to routine revolving facility draws.
children.name: Optional Specified Reps

children.definition: The subset of 10-12 representations that are actual closing conditions under the SunGard certain funds framework. Review Template row 51 lists common Specified Reps: 'existence, power, enforceability, solvency, margin regs, Investment Company Act, PATRIOT Act, OFAC/FCPA use-of-proceeds, creation/perfection.' DLS Preferred row 91 enumerates 34 representation categories, but under SunGard conditionality, only the Specified Reps must be accurate at closing. DLS Preferred row 11 alternative notes: 'Bring down of all representations and warranties only required if new incremental lenders require such condition; permit new lenders to only require bring down of specified reps if in connection with a Limited Condition Acquisition.' This tiering balances closing certainty against lender protection.
children.name: Specified Representations

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Limited to Borrower and restricted subs; Holdings only in limited circumstances
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: 34 enumerated representations applicable to Holdings and all subsidiaries: org status, capitalization, qualification, power/authority, enforceability, compliance, no defaults, no conflicts, consents, financial statements, no MAE, litigation, labor, property, environmental, taxes, ERISA, subs, margin regs, Investment Company Act, full disclosure, IP, solvency, Patriot/OFAC/FCPA, perfection/priority, location, insurance, holdco status, senior debt status, acquisition docs, use of proceeds, brokers

children.definition_source: Review Template row 51 (Specified Reps listing); DLS Preferred row 91 (34 representation categories); DLS Preferred row 11 (specified reps for incremental/LCA conditions)

children.definition: Documents required at closing: legal opinions (borrower + guarantor counsel), organizational certificates (good standing, incumbency), solvency certificate (CFO, consolidated basis), UCC filings, stock certificates.
children.name: At-Closing Deliverables
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 154 (Unknown); KCT Cat 1 Item 3

children.definition: Items deferred to 60-90 days post-closing: IP perfection filings (USPTO/USCO), foreign collateral perfection, mortgage recordings, DACAs, insurance certificates and endorsements.
children.name: Post-Closing Covenants

children.definition: Initial funding conditions: legal opinions, organizational certificates, solvency certificate, UCC filings, stock certificates, PATRIOT Act information (5 business days pre-closing), notice of borrowing. [4): Ability to request KYC information only available up to date of commitment paper signing, or additional information limited to changes in rules and re]
children.name: Closing Conditions

children.definition: Conditions for each subsequent borrowing: no default/EoD, specified reps true (materiality-qualified or flat bring-down), compliance certificate with pro forma calculations. []
children.name: Ongoing Borrowing Conditions

children.definition: SunGard provision allowing borrower to fix covenant metrics at signing date and test pro forma at closing. Scope: acquisitions (universal), investments, RPs, RDPs (expanding). Insulates from interim covenant drift.
children.name: Limited Condition Transaction

children.definition: Requirements that must be satisfied before initial or subsequent borrowings. DLS Preferred section 4 (Closing Conditions) establishes the framework. Review Template row 39 describes SunGard conditionality: 'UCC filings and stock certificates of borrower at close; other perfection steps move to post-closing.' Standard conditions for subsequent draws include: (i) no default or event of default, (ii) bring-down of representations, and (iii) delivery of borrowing notice. DLS Preferred row 14 (DDTL) lists 12 detailed conditions including pro forma leverage compliance, representation bring-down, environmental reports, QoE, and due diligence. KCT Category 3 item 10 flags that 'The existence of a Default should prohibit any borrowing of loans.'
children.name: Conditions Precedent

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Limited to Borrower and restricted subs; Holdings only in limited circumstances
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: 34 enumerated representations applicable to Holdings and all subsidiaries: org status, capitalization, qualification, power/authority, enforceability, compliance, no defaults, no conflicts, consents, financial statements, no MAE, litigation, labor, property, environmental, taxes, ERISA, subs, margin regs, Investment Company Act, full disclosure, IP, solvency, Patriot/OFAC/FCPA, perfection/priority, location, insurance, holdco status, senior debt status, acquisition docs, use of proceeds, brokers

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred section 4 (Closing Conditions framework); DLS Preferred row 14 (12 DDTL conditions); Review Template row 39 (SunGard collateral conditionality); KCT Category 3 item 10 (Default prohibition on borrowings)

children.definition: Transaction MAC (tied to specific acquisition — standard in PC) vs Market MAC (broad economic/market conditions — more common in BSL). Transaction MAC runs from signing to closing.
children.name: MAC Type
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 3 Item 8; Review Template Row 153 (MAC)

children.definition: Events excluded from MAC determination: war/hostilities, pandemic/epidemic, natural disaster, broad market changes, industry-wide changes, regulatory/legal changes. KCT flags war/hostilities carveouts as risk elevation.
children.name: MAC Carveouts
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 3 Item 8; KCT Cat 3 Item 11; KCT Cat 3 Item 14

children.definition: Whether carved-out events must 'disproportionately' affect the borrower relative to peers to be excluded. Merger agreement-type formulation requiring comparative analysis.
children.name: Disproportionate Effect Qualifier

children.definition: Importing M&A MAC carveouts into credit agreements creates a higher bar for calling a MAC, requiring comparative industry analysis rather than absolute deterioration.
children.name: Seasonal fluctuation exclusion

children.definition: Material Adverse Change/Effect definition determining whether significant deterioration has occurred between signing and closing. KCT Category 3 item 8 flags: 'MAE language has "merger agreement" type carve-outs which require that an event disproportionately affect the borrower.' KCT footnote 12 explains: '"Merger Agreement" carveouts are those found in a purchase and sale agreement and typically limit the ability to call a MAE on the target by carving out certain business events which do not qualify as a MAE.' KCT Category 3 item 11(b) further flags: 'the MAE or MAC definition in a credit agreement expressly carves out act(s) of war, hostilities, or escalation(s) of such act(s) of war or hostilities.' The MAC is a critical protection that allows lenders to refuse funding if the borrower's business has materially deteriorated.

REP_MATERIAL_ADVERSE_CHANGE.label: Material Adverse Change/Effect (MAC/MAE)
exactPhrases: could reasonably be expected to have a Material Adverse Effect
could reasonably be expected to have a Material Adverse Effect

market_benchmarks.kct_cat3_benchmark_addition: Add market benchmarks for prevalence and aggressiveness of MAE Merger-Agreement Carve-outs provisions across PC/BSL segments.

children.name: Material Adverse Effect Definition

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Limited to Borrower and restricted subs; Holdings only in limited circumstances
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: 34 enumerated representations applicable to Holdings and all subsidiaries: org status, capitalization, qualification, power/authority, enforceability, compliance, no defaults, no conflicts, consents, financial statements, no MAE, litigation, labor, property, environmental, taxes, ERISA, subs, margin regs, Investment Company Act, full disclosure, IP, solvency, Patriot/OFAC/FCPA, perfection/priority, location, insurance, holdco status, senior debt status, acquisition docs, use of proceeds, brokers

children.definition_source: KCT Category 3 item 8 and footnote 12 (MAE merger-agreement carveouts, disproportionate effect requirement); KCT Category 3 item 11(b) (MAE carveout for war/hostilities)

children.name: Default Scope Coverage
children.definition: Whether the representation covers Defaults only, Events of Default only, or both — and whether it extends to defaults under other material agreements beyond the credit agreement itself.

children.name: Bring-Down Timing
children.definition: When the no-default representation must be true — at closing, at each borrowing date, at each interest period date — and whether bring-down applies to both incurrence and ongoing conditions.

children.name: SunGard/Certain Funds Carve-Out
children.definition: Under SunGard conditionality, whether the no-default condition is limited to payment and bankruptcy defaults only — excluding financial covenant breaches and other technical defaults during the certain-funds period.

Borrower certifies no Default or Event of Default exists or will result from the borrowing. KCT Category 3 item 10 flags: 'The existence of a Default should prohibit any borrowing of loans -- i.e., there should be no ability to borrow any loans if a Default is continuing.' KCT footnote 13 notes: 'Rollover requests of existing drawn loans can be subject to no EoD or other more lenient constructs. This applies only to new money drawdowns that are not subject to Sungard or similar certain funds provisions.' The no-default condition is one of the standard conditions to subsequent borrowings alongside bring-down of representations and delivery of borrowing notice.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=easy vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: No Default / No EoD Representation

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Limited to Borrower and restricted subs; Holdings only in limited circumstances
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: 34 enumerated representations applicable to Holdings and all subsidiaries: org status, capitalization, qualification, power/authority, enforceability, compliance, no defaults, no conflicts, consents, financial statements, no MAE, litigation, labor, property, environmental, taxes, ERISA, subs, margin regs, Investment Company Act, full disclosure, IP, solvency, Patriot/OFAC/FCPA, perfection/priority, location, insurance, holdco status, senior debt status, acquisition docs, use of proceeds, brokers

children.definition_source: KCT Category 3 item 10 and footnote 13 (Default prohibition on borrowings; rollover exception)

children.definition: Whether reps must be true 'in all material respects' (standard) or 'in all respects' (bank preferred). Double-materiality scrub: reps already containing materiality qualifiers should not receive additional materiality overlay.
children.name: Materiality Qualification

children.definition: All representations must be true as of borrowing date, not just as of original representation date. More protective for lenders; captures intervening deterioration.
dls_ref: DLS:11:Conditions to incurrence: Bring down of
children.name: Flat Bring-Down
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 11 (Conditions to incurrence: Bring down of); KCT Cat 5 Item 2

children.definition: Accuracy standard for representations at each borrowing: material respects qualification (standard), flat bring-down (all respects — more protective), or specified-rep-only bring-down (SunGard minimum).
dls_ref: DLS:11:Conditions to incurrence: Bring down of

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Bring-Down Mechanics

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Limited to Borrower and restricted subs; Holdings only in limited circumstances
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: 34 enumerated representations applicable to Holdings and all subsidiaries: org status, capitalization, qualification, power/authority, enforceability, compliance, no defaults, no conflicts, consents, financial statements, no MAE, litigation, labor, property, environmental, taxes, ERISA, subs, margin regs, Investment Company Act, full disclosure, IP, solvency, Patriot/OFAC/FCPA, perfection/priority, location, insurance, holdco status, senior debt status, acquisition docs, use of proceeds, brokers

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 11 (Conditions to incurrence: Bring down of); DLS Preferred Row 57 (Specified Representations); KCT Cat 5 Item 2; Review Template Row 22 ([DDTL – conditions to draw])

children.definition: Minimum dollar amount of defaulted third-party indebtedness required to trigger a cross-default event of default under the credit agreement. The threshold (typically $25M-$75M, scaled to borrower size) prevents immaterial defaults on trade obligations or minor facilities from cascading into the credit facility, while ensuring that defaults on material obligations are captured.
children.name: Dollar Threshold

children.definition: EBITDA-based percentage threshold for cross-default (10-35% of Consolidated EBITDA). Provides company-size scaling.
children.name: EBITDA Percentage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 42 (Minimum EBITDA); DLS Preferred Row 72 (EBITDA)

children.definition: Materiality standards for cross-default triggers linking defaults under other debt instruments to the credit facility. DLS Preferred row 90 clause (v) specifies 'cross default and cross acceleration to material indebtedness' (highlighted for negotiation). The cross-default trigger is calibrated through the definition of 'material indebtedness' (typically a dollar threshold) and whether cross-default (any default under other debt) or only cross-acceleration (other lenders have actually accelerated) triggers the EoD. Alternative: limited to 'material' restricted subsidiaries or a group that would be material.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Cross-Default Thresholds

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Limited to Borrower and restricted subs; Holdings only in limited circumstances
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: 34 enumerated representations applicable to Holdings and all subsidiaries: org status, capitalization, qualification, power/authority, enforceability, compliance, no defaults, no conflicts, consents, financial statements, no MAE, litigation, labor, property, environmental, taxes, ERISA, subs, margin regs, Investment Company Act, full disclosure, IP, solvency, Patriot/OFAC/FCPA, perfection/priority, location, insurance, holdco status, senior debt status, acquisition docs, use of proceeds, brokers

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 90 clause (v) (highlighted: cross default and cross acceleration to material indebtedness)

children.name: Covered Agreements Scope
children.definition: Which agreements are tested for inconsistency — organizational documents, material contracts, other debt instruments, joint venture agreements — and whether the rep covers the borrower only or extends to all restricted subsidiaries.

children.name: Inconsistency Standard
children.definition: The threshold for what constitutes an 'inconsistency' — direct conflict with credit agreement terms, material adverse effect on lender rights, or any provision that could limit the borrower's ability to perform its obligations.

children.name: Remediation Obligation
children.definition: Whether the borrower must cure inconsistencies discovered post-closing — amend conflicting agreements, obtain waivers, or report to lenders — and the timeframe for remediation before it becomes a default.
Negative covenant prohibiting contractual arrangements inconsistent with loan document obligations. Only 16.7% adopt this covenant; 77.8% have no such restriction.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Inconsistent Agreements

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Limited to Borrower and restricted subs; Holdings only in limited circumstances
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: 34 enumerated representations applicable to Holdings and all subsidiaries: org status, capitalization, qualification, power/authority, enforceability, compliance, no defaults, no conflicts, consents, financial statements, no MAE, litigation, labor, property, environmental, taxes, ERISA, subs, margin regs, Investment Company Act, full disclosure, IP, solvency, Patriot/OFAC/FCPA, perfection/priority, location, insurance, holdco status, senior debt status, acquisition docs, use of proceeds, brokers

children.definition: Lender right to request updated KYC and beneficial ownership information from the borrower on an ongoing basis post-closing, including changes in control persons, 25% equity holders, and management certification.
children.name: Information Rights

children.definition: Whether KYC information requests are limited to information available as of the commitment paper signing date, creating a temporal cutoff that prevents lenders from imposing additional diligence requirements after commitment.
children.name: Commitment Paper Kyc Cutoff

children.definition: Right to request additional beneficial ownership information necessitated by changes in applicable anti-money-laundering, sanctions, or know-your-customer regulations occurring after the closing date.
children.name: Regulatory Change Information Rights

children.definition: KCT cat5.4 requires the protective mechanism 'ongoing KYC information rights' but it is not adequately represented in the ontology.
children.name: ongoing KYC information rights

children.definition: KYC and beneficial ownership compliance certification required under the Corporate Transparency Act and FinCEN Beneficial Ownership Rule. Must be delivered pre-closing and updated upon material changes.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

market_benchmarks.commitment_paper_cutoff_adoption_rate: [cat5.4] KCT cat5.4 requires prevalence/severity data for 'commitment-paper-cutoff adoption rate' but no existing node provides this benchmark.
market_benchmarks.prevalence_of_kyc_limitations: [cat5.4] KCT cat5.4 requires prevalence/severity data for 'prevalence of KYC limitations' but no existing node provides this benchmark.

children.name: Beneficial Ownership Certification

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Limited to Borrower and restricted subs; Holdings only in limited circumstances
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: 34 enumerated representations applicable to Holdings and all subsidiaries: org status, capitalization, qualification, power/authority, enforceability, compliance, no defaults, no conflicts, consents, financial statements, no MAE, litigation, labor, property, environmental, taxes, ERISA, subs, margin regs, Investment Company Act, full disclosure, IP, solvency, Patriot/OFAC/FCPA, perfection/priority, location, insurance, holdco status, senior debt status, acquisition docs, use of proceeds, brokers

children.definition: Force majeure guarantee releases reduce the credit package during exactly the kind of systemic event when protection is most needed.
children.name: Escalation clause scope

children.definition: provision releasing a guarantor from guarantee obligations or carving out from the MAE/MAC definition act(s) of war, hostilities, escalation of hostilities, or terrorism, flagged as a key risk that undermines lender protection during geopolitical crises
children.name: War/terrorism/hostilities carve-out

children.definition: carve-out from excluded event or force majeure provisions for cyber-attacks or cyber-security incidents, an emerging risk category that may release guarantors or prevent MAE triggers during digital disruption events; not yet standardized but gaining focus alongside war and terrorism carve-outs
children.name: Cyber-attack carve-out

children.definition: effect of force majeure or excluded event provisions that prevent covenant breaches caused by the excluded event from maturing into events of default, thereby suspending the lenders' ability to accelerate or exercise remedies during systemic disruptions
children.name: EoD trigger prevention

children.definition: effect of force majeure or excluded event provisions that prevent the excluded event from triggering a drawstop condition, allowing borrowers to continue drawing on revolving facilities even when the event would otherwise constitute a default barring new borrowings
children.name: Drawstop prevention

children.definition: delineation of which obligations are affected by the force majeure carve-out: whether limited to guarantee release, MAE/MAC definition only, or extending to affirmative and negative covenant compliance, with guarantee and MAE treated as separate scope dimensions
children.name: Scope limitation (which covenants affected)
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 112 (Unknown); KCT Cat 1 Item 1

children.definition: temporal boundary on the duration of a force majeure carve-out, limiting how long the suspension of guarantee obligations, MAE triggers, or covenant compliance can persist; absence of a time limit is a risk factor analogous to missing outside dates in LCT provisions
children.name: Time limitation on carve-out

children.definition: Whether guarantor obligations are released upon force majeure events (war, hostilities, terrorism). KCT Category 3 item 11 flags two separate concerns: '(a) Guarantee that expressly releases a guarantor of its obligations to perform under the guarantee in the event of act(s) of war, hostilities, or escalation(s) of such act(s) of war or hostilities or any Force Majeure clauses' and '(b) the MAE or MAC definition in a credit agreement expressly carves out act(s) of war, hostilities, or escalation(s) of such act(s) of war or hostilities.' KCT Category 3 item 14 separately flags 'Excluded Matter/Permitted Transaction type carve-outs which expressly include items such as anything related to any pandemic, epidemic, natural disaster, act(s) of war, terrorism' resulting in inability to trigger EoD and/or drawstop.

market_benchmarks.kct_cat3_benchmark_enrichment: Enrich benchmarks with segment-specific data (LMM/CMM/UMM/BSL) for Force Majeure Guarantee Release / MAE War Carveout.

children.name: Force Majeure / War Guarantee Release

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Limited to Borrower and restricted subs; Holdings only in limited circumstances
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: 34 enumerated representations applicable to Holdings and all subsidiaries: org status, capitalization, qualification, power/authority, enforceability, compliance, no defaults, no conflicts, consents, financial statements, no MAE, litigation, labor, property, environmental, taxes, ERISA, subs, margin regs, Investment Company Act, full disclosure, IP, solvency, Patriot/OFAC/FCPA, perfection/priority, location, insurance, holdco status, senior debt status, acquisition docs, use of proceeds, brokers

children.definition_source: KCT Category 3 item 11 (force majeure: guarantee release and MAE carveout); KCT Category 3 item 14 (Excluded Matter carveouts for pandemic/war/terrorism)

children.name: Specified Representations List
children.definition: The enumerated subset of representations (typically 10-12 of 34) required to be true under SunGard certain funds conditionality — organization, authority, enforceability, no conflict, solvency, investment company, OFAC/sanctions, PATRIOT Act.
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 57 (Unknown); Review Template Row 150 (Unknown); KCT Cat 1 Item 3

children.name: Limited Conditions Precedent
children.definition: The reduced set of closing conditions applicable during the certain-funds period — delivery of acquisition agreement, specified reps true, no payment/bankruptcy default, no MAE — versus full closing conditions for non-acquisition draws.
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 2; Learning Material: 2) Transaction Description / Conditions Precedent

children.name: Bring-Down Standard
children.definition: Whether specified representations must be true in all material respects or in all respects at funding, and whether bring-down applies as of signing date or funding date — the precision of the truth-testing standard.

children.name: Expanded Scope Beyond Acquisitions
children.definition: Modern expansions of SunGard conditionality beyond acquisitions to cover other incurrence baskets — restricted payments, investments, incremental facilities — where limited conditions now apply to non-acquisition covenant usage.

Framework limiting closing conditions to Specified Reps plus Specified Acquisition Agreement Reps plus essential collateral, providing the borrower with closing certainty while preserving lender protections. Named after the 2005 SunGard LBO that established the template. Review Template row 51: 'Specified Representations' include existence, power, enforceability, solvency, margin regulations, Investment Company Act, PATRIOT Act, OFAC/FCPA, use-of-proceeds, creation/perfection. Review Template row 39: UCC filings and stock certificates at closing, other perfection post-closing. Learning Material section on Conditions Precedent covers the certain funds framework in detail. The framework ensures the sponsor can close the M&A transaction on time (closing certainty) while the bank receives minimum baseline protections.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

market_benchmarks.standard: limited conditions: no MAE, specified reps, no EoD from payment default

children.name: Sungard Conditionality
children.definition_source: Review Template rows 39, 51 (Sungard collateral and specified reps); Learning Material section on Conditions Precedent (certain funds framework)

children.name: Jury Trial Waiver
children.definition: Mutual waiver of jury trial rights in any litigation arising under or relating to the credit agreement. Standard in virtually all leveraged finance credit agreements. Reduces litigation uncertainty and is considered a fundamental borrower-lender protection.

children.name: Waiver Scope
children.definition: Defines which parties are bound by the jury trial waiver (borrower, guarantors, administrative agent, all lenders, letter of credit issuers) and which claims are covered (contract, tort, statutory). Broadest formulations cover 'any proceeding arising out of or relating to' the loan documents, while narrow versions limit to disputes under the credit agreement itself.
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 149 (Unknown); KCT Cat 1 Item 2

children.name: Enforceability Considerations
children.definition: State-law variations affecting enforceability of pre-dispute jury trial waivers. Most states enforce contractual jury waivers between sophisticated commercial parties, but certain jurisdictions impose heightened standards (knowing, voluntary, intelligent waiver). California historically disfavored pre-dispute waivers, though federal courts in California generally enforce them under diversity jurisdiction.

children.name: Standard / LSTA Model Language
children.definition: The LSTA model credit agreement includes a standard mutual jury trial waiver provision, typically in the miscellaneous article (Article X or XI). Language is largely boilerplate with minimal negotiation, though certain borrowers may resist inclusion where governing law jurisdiction does not clearly enforce pre-dispute waivers. Presence/absence is binary — there is no graduated version.

extraction_refs.search_strategy: Full-text search for jury trial waiver, waiver of jury trial, JURY TRIAL
extraction_refs.notes: Standard boilerplate provision; look for WAIVER OF JURY TRIAL heading or inline waiver language

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 149 (Unknown); KCT Cat 1 Item 3

children.name: Labor Matters Representation
children.definition: Representation that no material labor disputes, strikes, or collective bargaining issues exist that could reasonably be expected to have a Material Adverse Effect. May include affirmative covenant to maintain labor relations.

children.name: Scope of Labor Matters Covered
children.definition: Defines the categories of labor-related issues subject to the representation: strikes, lockouts, work stoppages, unfair labor practice charges, collective bargaining agreements (CBAs), union organizing activities, WARN Act compliance, and ERISA/benefit plan matters. Broader formulations include wage-and-hour compliance and independent contractor classification disputes.

children.name: Materiality Qualifier
children.definition: The threshold at which labor matters become reportable or constitute a breach of the representation. Most CAs use the standard 'could reasonably be expected to have a Material Adverse Effect' qualifier, though some add 'individually or in the aggregate' language. Key negotiation point: whether the MAE qualifier applies to all sub-categories or only to certain types of labor disputes (e.g., CBA status may be reported without MAE qualification).

children.name: Ongoing Obligation / Affirmative Covenant
children.definition: Whether the labor matters representation is supplemented by an affirmative covenant requiring the borrower to maintain satisfactory labor relations or to notify the administrative agent of material labor disputes as they arise. Some CAs include labor matters in the event-notice affirmative covenant rather than as a standalone obligation. The bring-down mechanics (closing only vs. each credit extension) affect the ongoing nature.

extraction_refs.search_strategy: Full-text search for labor matters, employment matters, collective bargaining, WARN Act
extraction_refs.typical_location: ARTICLE III (Representations and Warranties) or ARTICLE V (Affirmative Covenants)
extraction_refs.notes: Look for labor disputes, strikes, lockouts, CBAs, WARN Act compliance, ERISA matters

children.name: Minimum Credit Ratings Requirement
children.definition: Condition precedent or ongoing covenant requiring the borrower to obtain or maintain minimum credit ratings from specified agencies. DLS Row 43: Preferred position is no minimum rating requirement, but with 'undertaking to use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain ratings.' Alternative: required for syndicated deals only. More common in broadly syndicated leveraged loans where ratings affect CLO eligibility and secondary market trading.

children.name: Rating Agencies
children.definition: Specified rating agencies from which ratings must be obtained: S&P Global Ratings, Moody's Investors Service, and/or Fitch Ratings. Typically requires ratings from at least two of the three major agencies.

children.name: Minimum Rating Levels
children.definition: Minimum credit rating levels that must be maintained. For leveraged loans, typically B-/B3 corporate family rating. For investment-grade crossover facilities, BBB-/Baa3. May specify separate corporate and facility-level ratings.

children.name: Consequences of Downgrade
children.definition: Remedial actions or consequences triggered by a credit rating downgrade: pricing step-up (margin increase), additional collateral posting requirements, mandatory prepayment triggers, or event of default. May distinguish between downgrade below minimum and withdrawal of rating.

children.name: Business MAC (Material Adverse Change)
children.definition: Closing condition requiring no material adverse change in the borrower's business, financial condition, or operations since a specified date, distinct from the ongoing MAE definition used in representations and warranties. DLS Row 44: Defined in commitment papers and aligned with the acquisition agreement's MAC definition as in effect on the date of the commitment letter. The acquisition agreement MAC definition is subject to satisfactory review prior to signing, and subsequent changes are deemed materially adverse to lenders. This is a key condition precedent that determines whether the committed financing must fund.

children.name: Baseline Date
children.definition: Reference date from which material adverse change is measured. Typically the date of the most recent audited financial statements delivered prior to signing or the date of the acquisition agreement. The lookback period determines the scope of business performance that must be maintained.

children.name: MAC Carveouts
children.definition: Exclusions from the business MAC determination: changes in general economic conditions, industry-wide conditions, financial market disruptions, changes in law or GAAP, pandemic or public health conditions, acts of war or terrorism, and seasonal fluctuations. Heavily negotiated; breadth of carveouts determines practical invocability of the MAC condition.
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 153 (Unknown); KCT Cat 1 Item 1

children.name: Sunlight Provisions
children.definition: SunGard-style provisions that limit the lender's ability to invoke the business MAC condition. May require that the MAC must be material to the target and its subsidiaries taken as a whole, may limit MAC invocation to the same standard as the acquisition agreement, or may provide a disproportionate-effect qualifier requiring that the impact affect the borrower more than similarly situated companies.
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; PC Term Comparison: 7. Events of Default - 8.Admin Agency Provisions

definition: Framework of representations and warranties (risk-allocation statements about the borrower's condition) and conditions precedent (requirements that must be satisfied before funding). DLS Preferred specifies 34 categories of representations and warranties covering organizational status, capitalization, power/authority, enforceability, compliance with laws, no defaults, no conflicts, consents, financial statements, no MAE, litigation, labor, property, environmental, taxes, ERISA, subsidiaries, margin regulations, Investment Company Act, disclosure, IP, solvency, sanctions/OFAC/FCPA, liens/perfection, collateral location, insurance, holdco status, senior debt status, acquisition documents, use of proceeds, and broker fees. For acquisition financing under Sungard conditionality, closing date reps are limited to 'Specified Representations' (existence, power, enforceability, solvency, margin regulations, Investment Company Act, PATRIOT Act, OFAC/FCPA use of proceeds, lien creation/perfection) plus 'Acquisition Agreement Representations' (only to the extent the borrower has the right to terminate the acquisition). All other reps are brought down at each subsequent credit extension, qualified by materiality (with no double-materiality).
name: Reps & Conditions
definition_source: DLS Preferred rows 57 (Specified Representations with complete enumeration), 91 (34 R&W categories); Review Template rows 51 (Reps and Warranties); Intro Guide Representations and Warranties section (MAE qualification, materiality qualification, knowledge qualification, bring-down mechanics)
